Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Leveraging advances in stable isotope probing to investigate phylogenetic organization in prokaryotic activity
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is estimated that there are more than one trillion species of microorganisms Earth, but only a small fraction of them have been isolated, grown in the laboratory and fully characterized. This project will support the development of a novel approach that links the identification of the vast diversity of microorganisms with their role in consuming different carbon sources in soil without the need to isolate and cultivate them in the laboratory. It will take advantage of the latest developments in DNA sequencing and environmental chemistry. Specifically, this research will also test whether related microorganisms decompose the same forms of carbon in soil, resulting a major advance in microbial evolution and ecology. This work will also result in an important new tool to characterize microbial biodiversity in order to better predict the cycling of carbon in soil.

This Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will investigate the role of evolutionary history in determining microbial function via the study of an integral ecosystem process: carbon decomposition. A novel method that quantitatively measures stable isotope incorporation into the nucleic acids of individual microbial "species" (or phylotypes) will be used to determine which microorganisms are decomposing and assimilating specific constituents of the soil carbon pool. The soil carbon compounds to be considered include important representatives from plants and microbes (e.g. cellulose, proteins) and range from quickly mineralized (i.e. glucose and amino acids) to recalcitrant (i.e. cellulose) carbon sources. Comparing the activity and phylogeny of microorganisms will allow a determination of whether closely related organisms tend to consume the same carbon sources. To determine if the functional roles of microbial phylotypes and phylogenetic groups are consistent under different environmental conditions, soils with differing soil organic carbon characteristics will be studied. As soil organic carbon quantity and chemistry influences the composition and activity of microbial communities, this comparison will provide insight into which organisms and activities are consistent under different environmental conditions. If evolutionary history is found to be a determinant of microbial function, phylogeny/function relationships will be characterized in order to understand how the composition of microbial communities affects their functioning within ecosystems. In addition to charting new ground in environmental microbiology, this project will support two undergraduate student researchers and an early-career investigator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soil is the largest terrestrial reservoir of carbon; microbial decomposition determines how much carbon entering soil from plants is sequestered or returned to atmosphere as carbon dioxide. Consequently, we must understand microorganisms to accurately predict the flow of carbon. Within ecosystems the species composition of plants and animals drives ecosystem function; however, whether this is also true for microorganisms remains unclear. Given the tremendous diversity and abundance of microorganisms, and their very small size, scaling from individual microbial species to ecosystem level processes has been particularly challenging. This award aimed to help bridge this gap using an innovative stable isotope probing approach. This method measures the activities of individual microbial species. We hypothesized that closely related species would have similar activity rates due to their shared evolutionary history. This influence of evolutionary history (aka phylogeny) could help us predict the activity of uncharacterized microorganisma and group functionally similar, closely related organisms together for ease of modeling.

To test the hypothesis of phylogenetic organization in the activity of microorganisms performing decomposition we collected soil from an experiment that manipulated leaf litter inputs. By collecting from plots with no, double, and normal leaf litter inputs we were able to determine how historical differences in carbon availability impact the activity of microorganisms. To assess microbial decomposition activity, we used stable isotope enriched (13C) substrates representative of major classes of biomolecules entering soil from plants. Specifically, we added 13C-labelled glucose, cellulose, amino acids, and lipids to soil and followed the isotope into the nucleic acids of individual microbial species to measure species-specific carbon assimilation and decomposition activity. We also measured carbon dioxide production from these substrates over time to determine how the activity of microbial species was related to decomposition rates.

Results indicate that historical litter inputs altered the decomposition rates of the added substrates. Specifically, rates were slower in the soil without leaf litter inputs. Further, the four substrates differed in their rates of decomposition. Glucose and amino acids were rapidly utilized by the microbial community as ~40% of the substrate was evolved as carbon dioxide within a week. Microbial utilization of lipids was limited since ~90% of the lipid carbon remained in the soil after six weeks. The decomposition of cellulose also proceeded more slowly than glucose and amino acids with ~60% remaining by 3 weeks. Differences in the decomposition of these substrates corresponded with carbon incorporation by soil microorganisms. Many microbial species assimilated carbon from glucose and amino acids into their DNA, while carbon incorporation from cellulose and lipids was restricted to comparatively few groups. The results supported our hypothesis that closely related species would have similar substrate assimilation profiles (Fig 1). Evolutionary history influenced carbon assimilation for all four substrates. Since most microorganisms can utilize glucose and amino acids, our results suggest the amount of assimilation is dependent on the microorganisms' growth rate, where fast growing bacterial families such as Psuedomonadacea and Micrococcaceae have high amounts of carbon assimilation. In contrast, cellulose and lipid utilization was restricted to specialized bacterial families such as Cytophagaceae and Moraxellaceae respectively. The evolutionary patterns were consistent across litter input treatments, indicating that decomposition activity can cluster according to evolutionary history even across environmental variation. Further, the connections between microbial diversity and decomposition observed here can be used to understand how microbial community composition can influence ecosystem function. For instance, communities with large populations of Cytophagaceae will likely exhibit higher rates of cellulose decomposition than soils with lower abundance of cellulose-degrading microbial groups. 

In summary, the influence of evolutionary history we observed suggests that we can group closely related organisms (e.g. species within a family), that have similar ecological functions (e.g. lipid decomposition). As a soil community can have thousands of microbial species, grouping species together may allow us to reduce this complexity in order to incorporate aspects of microbial biodiversity into ecosystem models to better predict, and possibly even manage, the flow of carbon on our changing planet.

With respect to broader impacts, this award provided support to an early career, female, principal investigator in West Virginia, a state with below average scientific funding. This award helped jump start Dr. Morrissey's career by providing critical proof of concept data which she has successfully used to acquire additional federal research grants. Opportunities for a female graduate student and laboratory technician to participate in science were provided by this award. Both of these junior scientist acquired skill in the laboratory as well as data analysis and scientific communication. This grant supported further opportunities for professional development by enabling the female graduate student and laboratory technician to attend and present research findings at an international scientific meeting.
